Policy Considerations Governing the Protection of Intellectual Property

para.paratext: … property guards the troubled boundary between individual man and the state … in a society that chiefly values material well-being, the power to control a particular portion of the well-being, is the very foundation of individuality.[1]

Intellectual property rights have to do with the protection of products of the mind and with the expression of ideas, using the paradigm of property law. The value of information lies in the ability to restrict access to that information. The courts seek to balance restricted access to and dissemination of information so that inventors are encouraged to create and society may benefit from the new information.[2] The key question in determining how the courts should protect intellectual property is to decide where the line should be drawn between the right to copy and the right to prevent copying. Where dissemination of information is in the public interest, those who copy should be encouraged to improve on the idea.[3] Ideas must be developed or applied; to protect an idea before it has begun to be implemented could stultify economic progress and efficiency.[4]
C.A. Reich, “The New Property” (1964), 73 Yale L.J. 733.
M. Chromocek and S. McCormack, World Intellectual Property Guidebook (New York: Mathew Bender & Co. Inc., 1988), p. 1-12.
